content.title: Ischemic Rest Pain
content.definition: Severe persistent pain in the foot and toes occurring at rest, typically at night, due to critically reduced arterial perfusion inadequate to meet basal metabolic demands. It represents Fontaine stage III and Rutherford category 4, and is a defining criterion for chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).

key_concepts.description: Multi-level arterial occlusive disease reduces perfusion pressure below critical closing pressure of capillaries (~20-30 mmHg); at rest, cardiac output falls, and recumbent position eliminates gravity-assisted perfusion to feet

Pain worsens at night when cardiac output decreases during sleep; patients characteristically hang foot off bed or sleep in chair to use gravity to improve perfusion - a classic board question scenario
Pain typically begins in forefoot/toes (most distal tissue), described as burning, aching, or severe cramping; may extend proximally with worsening ischemia
Patients learn to dangle legs or stand to use gravity to increase perfusion pressure (~100 mmHg per meter of height); this creates dependent rubor and may lead to dependent edema
Ankle pressure <50 mmHg or toe pressure <30 mmHg typically required to develop rest pain; corresponds to ABI <0.4 in most patients
Pallor with elevation (elevation pallor), rubor with dependency (dependent rubor); Buerger's angle <20 degrees (angle at which pallor appears with leg elevation); capillary refill >3 seconds
Without revascularization, 1-year amputation rate 40-50%; 1-year mortality 25%. Represents urgency for intervention to prevent tissue loss and limb loss

Peripheral neuropathy (diabetes) - numbness predominates, no positional relief; Nocturnal leg cramps - brief, muscle-related, no ischemic signs; Complex regional pain syndrome - autonomic features; Gout - joint involvement
Rest pain is a vascular emergency requiring urgent evaluation and revascularization planning; medical optimization concurrent with imaging workup
Pain control often requires opioids; however, opioid-induced hypotension can worsen ischemia; position optimization (sitting/dependency) is critical adjunct

explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Ischemic Rest Pain.

learning_objectives: Define ischemic rest pain and distinguish from claudication
Recognize the characteristic nocturnal pattern and positional relief
Appreciate the urgency - this is a limb-threatening emergency
clinical_pearls: Patient sleeping in chair or with foot dangling = think rest pain
Pain at rest that improves with dependency = ischemia, not neuropathy
Neuropathy: numbness predominates, no positional relief
Buerger's angle <20° = severe ischemia (pallor appears quickly with elevation)
Rest pain = CLTI = urgent revascularization needed
common_mistakes: Dismissing as neuropathy in diabetics (they can have both)
Delaying referral - rest pain is urgent/emergent
Using vasoconstrictors for blood pressure support (worsens ischemia)
Overlooking the significance of sleeping in a chair
